docs.lead_paragraph: AARP said drug prices jumped 3.9 percent, four times the general inflation rate during the first quarter of this year.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 2 Bodies Found in Iraq Were Brutalized, U.S. Says The American military said that searchers had found the remains of what appeared to be the two American soldiers captured by insurgents last week during an ambush south of the capital, and a senior Iraqi defense official said the two men had been ''brutally tortured.'' A1 As the Senate prepares for a bitter debate about whether to begin pulling troops from Iraq, Senator John Kerry insists on setting a date for all American combat troops to be withdrawn, frustrating some Senate Democrats who say in interviews that his new stand may complicate their hopes of taking back a majority in Congress in 2006. A1 Japan announced it would start pulling its ground troops out of Iraq, putting an end to the country's most significant military mission since the end of World War II. A8 The Pentagon announced that it planned to send 21,000 troops to Iraq in the next phase of its force rotation, a schedule that would maintain the American military presence at current levels into next year. A9 Israeli Attack Kills 3 Children An Israeli aircraft fired on a car that officials suspected was carrying armed Palestinian militants in Gaza and killed three children nearby, hospital officials and witnesses said. A4 North Korea Defiant on Pledge North Korea said it was not bound by its own moratorium on long-range missile tests, as tension over Pyongyang's missile intentions continued to mount. A9 NATIONAL A10-15 House Plan May Delay Immigration Overhaul In a decision that puts the overhaul of immigration laws in serious doubt, House Republican leaders said they would hold summer hearings around the nation on the subject before trying to compromise with the Senate on a chief domestic priority of President Bush. A1 Encyclopedia for Conservatism Sixteen years in the making, American Conservatism: An Encyclopedia appears with American conservatism, the political movement, warring over its future direction. A1 Depression in New Orleans New Orleans is experiencing what appears to be a near-epidemic of depression and post-traumatic stress disorders, one that mental health experts say is of an intensity rarely seen in this country. It is contributing to a suicide rate that officials describe as close to triple what it was before Hurricane Katrina struck. A1 Conviction in Lobby Case A former White House aide, David H. Safavian, left, was convicted of lying to government investigators about his ties to the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff, in the first trial to result from the influence-peddling inquiry centered on Mr. Abramoff. A14 U.S. Lacks Plan for Avian Flu The Agriculture Department lacks a comprehensive plan for detecting avian flu in poultry and wild birds, its inspector general's office said. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Leaders Resolve Issues As Legislative Session Ends New York State lawmakers rushing to finish their business for the year agreed to overhaul the state's pursuit of Medicaid fraud, and they were completing agreements to eliminate the statute of limitations in rape cases and to broadly expand the state's DNA database. A1 New 9/11 Memorial Design The reconceived World Trade Center memorial and museum, unveiled after weeks of anxious anticipation, attempts to solve security problems, placate disaffected family members and bring the project closer to the $500 million budget cap set last month by Governor Pataki and Mayor Bloomberg. B1 A Mayor Admits Drug Use John M. Fabrizi, the Democratic mayor of Bridgeport, Conn., admitted publicly, while fighting back tears, that he had abused cocaine and alcohol since his election in April 2003. B1 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-6 Miami Wins NBA Title Dwyane Wade again led the way, scoring 36 points, as the Miami Heat defeated the Dallas Mavericks 95-92 to capture its first N.B.A. title. D1 OBITUARIES B10 Vincent Sherman One of Hollywood's last surviving studio-era directors, he was 99. B10 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 G.O.P. and Estate Tax In a new gambit to reduce permanently the estate tax on inherited wealth, House Republican leaders moved to win over crucial Democrats with a tax sweetener for timber companies. C1 Prescription Prices Soar Prices of the most widely used prescription drugs rose sharply in this year's first quarter, just as the new Medicare drug coverage program was going into effect, according to separate studies issued by two large consumer advocacy groups. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A16-17 Editorials: The New Orleans muddle; Iraq, unfiltered; razzle-dazzle 'em ethics reform; emergency in the emergency rooms. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd. Crossword E4 TV Listings E9 Weather D8

docs.lead_paragraph: Toxoplasma gondii infects over half the world's population. Scientists are now discovering some of the secrets of the parasite's success.

docs.lead_paragraph: CLEARED The News -- The special prosecutor in the C.I.A. leak case decided not to bring charges against Karl Rove. Behind the News -- Last fall, it seemed that an indictment on perjury charges was imminent for Mr. Rove, the president's senior adviser, as part of the leak investigation. The decision not to charge him eliminates a major distraction for the White House and allows Mr. Rove to focus on the midterm elections. But a cloud hangs over the executive branch: I. Lewis Libby, Vice President Dick Cheney's former chief of staff and the only person charged in the investigation, is expected to go on trial on perjury and obstruction of justice charges in January. Mr. Cheney may be called to testify. PLEADED The News -- Representative Patrick J. Kennedy of Rhode Island pleaded guilty to driving under the influence of prescription drugs. Behind the News -- Mr. Kennedy, 38, the son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, was sentenced to court-ordered drug treatment and probation in connection with a late-night car crash last month near the Capitol. After the accident he denied he had been drinking, announced he was addicted to prescription painkillers and checked into the Mayo Clinic for a month of treatment. For Mr. Kennedy, it was the latest in a long line of revelations of personal troubles; the effect on his standing among the voters of his home state is yet to be seen. APPEALED The News -- The Supreme Court made it easier for death-row inmates to challenge states on the issue of lethal injection. Behind the News -- The justices ruled in the case of Clarence E. Hill, above, a Florida inmate who had been scheduled for execution last January for the killing of a police officer. The court said Mr. Hill could challenge Florida's method of lethal injection under the Civil Rights Act of 1871, an appeals route with few obstacles. Death penalty opponents have questioned whether the drugs used eliminate pain. If not, they say, it is a cruel and unusual punishment. In their ruling, the justices gave no indication of where they stand on the issue. FREED The News -- Abu Bakar Bashir, an Islamic cleric linked to the bombings of two nightclubs in Bali three years ago, was released from an Indonesian prison. Behind the News -- American officials said they were disappointed in the release of Mr. Bashir, whom they consider to be an important operative for Al Qaeda. Mr. Bashir had served a little over a year of a 30-month sentence after being convicted of conspiracy in connection with the bombings, which killed 202 people. The judges in the case said Mr. Bashir knew the perpetrators and may have encouraged them. But as he returned to his hometown there were signs his influence may be waning: the crowd that welcomed him was far smaller than expected. SUED The News -- KFC was sued by a nutrition advocacy group seeking to have it stop using partially hydrogenated oils in its fried chicken and other foods. Behind the News -- The lawsuit by the Center for Science in the Public Interest came after the group had unsuccessfully petitioned the Food and Drug Administration to require warning signs in restaurants regarding use of the oils, a major source of trans fats, which nutritionists consider unhealthy. KFC said the suit was frivolous and that the company took health issues seriously. It said it was reviewing the use of alternative oils, but that maintaining the flavor of the original Colonel Sanders fried chicken recipe was important.

headline.main: Legal Notes From All Over | June 11-17
